reviewText: Hacksaw Jim Duggan and Hart Foundation VS Dino Bravo and Rogeau Brothers in 2/3 falls match- A very good matchRick Rude VS Ultimate Warrior in a Pose down: This only served to make them wrestle at WrestleMania.Judy Martin VS Rockin Robin: SkipRoyal Rumble interviews abound, a very entertaining interview segement that WWE needs to do again.King Haku VS Harley Race: A slow paced but entertaining match. I liked how these two meshed together, Haku retains the crown in the end.Royal Rumble: A very good Rumble with a suprise winner.Overall, the two matches on the undercard were good but the women's match sucked. The Rumble was very good.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The first pay-per-view Royal Rumble (there was one prior on basic cable) was one of the defining moments in the WWF. The match itself featuring Demolition going at it with one another and the infamous altercation between Hulk Hogan and Macho Man that would lead to their split and eventual match at Wrestlemania V. The "Royal Rumble" concept was groundbreaking at the time because it was one of the only times that you would see the good guys fighting one another and vice versa with the bad guys. This was a well put together type of match where they didn't just throw out the obvious winner and play it off predictably.Sadly, the video version is notorious for cutting out a few of the matches that aired on the original PPV. It would be great if the WWF were to re-release all the Rumbles in a library collection similiar to the one they made with "Wrestlemania".
Title: N/A

reviewText: In January of 1989, the second WWF Royal Rumble took place in Houston, Texas, as the WWF attempted to expand its pay-per-view monopoly to four major events per year. Arguably, the 1989 rumble was the best of the Hulkamania era because it managed to keep the ending in suspense by not letting the announcers hint at who would actually win the event. Perhaps most importantly, this one match salvages an otherwise lackluster effort from Vince McMahon's WWF.1. Hacksaw Duggan & the Hart Foundation vs. Dino Bravo & the Rougeaus (two of three falls): With Jimmy Hart's help, the French Canadians initially gain the upper hand before Hacksaw and the Hart Foundation can take command in the final 2/3 of the match. 3 stars (it is a standard WWF tv main event).2. Rockin' Robin vs. Judy Martin for the WWF Women's Title: Although the WWF deserves credit for offering a women's match, this one is barely watchable, as you can imagine why the women's division sank into oblivion not long afterwards. Providing guest commentary and issuing threats at both competitors, Scary Sherri doesn't help the dreary situation much.1 1/2 stars3. I-C Champion Ultimate Warrior vs. Rick Rude in a posedown contest: This one is an obvious set-up for the inevitable Wrestlemania match to come. Still, it is worth a laugh to watch for its absurd tongue-in-cheek quality, as Rude and Bobby Heenan become increasingly agitated over the audience's preference for the Warrior. 2 stars (at best)4. The Royal Rumble:The 30 "entering at random" participants: Andre the Giant, Ron Garvin, Mr. Perfect, Greg Valentine, Tito Santana, Bad News Brown, WWF Champion Randy Savage, Jake Roberts, Hulk Hogan, Akeem (One Man Gang), Big Bossman, Brutus Beefcake, Red Rooster (Terry Taylor), Honky Tonk Man, Rick Martel, Ted DiBiase, Big John Studd, Hercules, Koko B. Ware, Ron Bass; and the following tag teams: Demolition, the Bushwhackers, Powers of Pain, the Rockers, and the Brain Busters (Tully Blanchard & Arn Anderson)Starting with Demolition's Ax and Smash facing off against each other, the match is a blast to watch. Among the highlights:- Ax, Smash, Mr. Perfect, Greg Valentine, and Ronnie Garvin teaming up against Andre the Giant- WWF Champion Randy Savage vs. Bad News Brown- the Brain Busters vs. Hulk Hogan- Hogan clearing the ring- an irrate Savage's confrontation with Hogan- Hogan facing Akeem & the Big Bossman- Big John Studd vs. Ted DiBiase & Virgil- the surprise winner provides a reason why the biggest stars doesn't always have to win the main event.- Savage's post-match interview5 stars!!Overall, you will likely be buying this WWF event for one awesome match (as the other features are just filler material to help pad the tape's running length to 2 hours). Still, if you can find this vhs for a reasonable price, the 1989 Royal Rumble is well worth viewing for wrestling fans of all ages.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Royal Rumble 1989 is one of the best examples of classic, cartoonish WWF, before it got stupid in the early 90s and totally different from its more edgy stuff that began shortly before the millennium.The Royal Rumble is a unique event. It is what's known as a battle royal, a type of match in which any number of wrestlers can be in the ring at one time, and a wrestler is eliminated from the contest if he is knocked out of the ring over the top rope. In the WF version, the "Royal Rumble", the rules are the same but with the added interest of having new participants enter the ring at timed intervals, usually 2 minutes apart. The last man alone in the ring is the winner.While this 1989 RR is not the first (there is a non-video Royal Rumble, the original which was aired on cable in 1988),this one's one of the best. It should come as no surprise to most fans that wrestling is preplanned (I hate saying "fake", that's not the right word). But the fun in this particular Royal Rumble is that they had fun with the idea. Old school wrestler the Million Dollar Man, in storyline, threw some of his vast resources around to influence which wrestlers entered, and in what order. This turned the supposedly random participantlist into one that was more or less "fixed" for fun results.For example, anyone who grew up loving the team "Demolition" (like me) get to see them have to fight each other. And the grand star of the WF, Hulk Hogan, at one point has to fight his two biggest rivals of the time (Akeem and the Big Bossman) all alone. I've been a fan of these events for some time (except for the miserable 1997 Royal Rumble), but this one is a standout due to the fun of coming right out and "fixing" the results (albeit in storyline).There are about half a dozen other matches on the card as well, but most of them are throwaways. The women's champ Rockin' Robyn fights a lady's title match, there's a tag match featuring the Hart Foundation and Hacksaw Jim Duggan (star of the first Royal Rumble), and Rick Rude has a silly "pose-down" against the Ultimate Warrior.But the main star is the hour long Royal Rumble. Not a lot of chance for actual athleticism occur in such matches, but there's a lot of fun and suspense waiting to see who'll come in next to throw some guys out.
summary: Royal Rumble 1989 is one of the best of its kind.

reviewText: After experimenting with the new "Royal Rumble" event in 1988, the WWF turned out a much stronger showing with this event, as it begins to take a life of its own instead of just serving as an appetizer for the big Wrestlemania event.The events of the big Rumble (especially involving Andre the Giant!) are hilarious as usual, with all sorts of shenanigans and crazy antics transpiring.  As a child, I was captivated by the drama of the event, but as an adult I almost look back at it as a comedy!One caveat: skip the preliminary matches that take place in advance of the main event.  They are poor matches and only serve to prolong character plots, not really advance them.
summary: Skip The Preliminaries, Enjoy The Rumble!
Title: N/A
